parameters.source_text:
CASE 92:
FEMALE GENITAL MUTILATION
Sayida, 21 years old, has recently arrived in the UK with her husband and 2-year-old daugh-
ter from their home country, Sierra Leone. The family left Sierra Leone because of war and
continuing political unrest and are seeking asylum in the UK. Sayida is 10 weeks pregnant
when she attends the antenatal clinic for her first booking appointment, accompanied by
her husband and a middle-aged female relative of her husband. The latter explains that she
has come along to act as chaperone and interpreter because Sayida speaks no English and
her husband very little. During initial assessment it transpires that a friend already living in
London has told Sayida about the African Well Woman Clinic (AWWC) and Sayida’s hus-
band has telephoned for an appointment. Through the interpreter Sayida explains that she
had problems with her first pregnancy and during the birth, and her friend has told her that
the AWWC would be able to help her with this and ‘difficulties’ she has had since the birth
of her daughter.
Clinical examination by a female genital mutilation (FGM) public health specialist reveals
that Sayida has FGM III and is presenting with symptoms consistent with problems associ-
ated with urinary tract infection and the menstrual cycle.
Questions
• What is FGM?
• What are the laws in the UK regarding the practice of FGM?
• Should a competent adult be able to consent to the procedure?
• What is cultural relativism?

data.vignette: A 21-year-old asylum seeker is 10 weeks pregnant and attends her first antenatal visit. She has limited English and arrives with her husband and an older female relative who is interpreting. Exam at a specialist clinic shows type III female genital cutting with a very small introitus. She reports chronic dysuria, difficulty with menses, and a traumatic prior delivery that required urgent cutting at the time of birth. She says she wants a safer, more controlled pregnancy this time, but also fears permanent genital change during pregnancy and worries about her family’s reaction if she is opened now. You are planning her obstetric care and must decide when, if at all, to perform deinfibulation. Hospital policy and current law allow elective deinfibulation either during pregnancy or at delivery with the patient’s informed consent. A decision is needed soon to plan staffing and delivery location.
data.choice_1: Schedule deinfibulation during the second trimester
data.choice_2: Defer deinfibulation and plan to perform it only at delivery

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Rephrase language that implies one timing is medically superior. For example, change “wants a safer, more controlled pregnancy this time” to “hopes to avoid an unplanned emergency incision during labor” and explicitly note that either timing is clinically acceptable but carries different types of risks (e.g., second-trimester procedure risks: bleeding/infection/pain/psychological distress; intrapartum procedure risks: need for urgent incision, limited time for anesthesia/consent, higher risk of perineal trauma). Avoid wording that frames antepartum deinfibulation as the objectively ‘safer’ option.

decision_forcing_context.suggested_changes: Make the time pressure concrete and clinically realistic. E.g., add: “Her next visit is in 2 weeks, and if deinfibulation is planned during pregnancy it needs to be scheduled before 20–24 weeks to coordinate anesthesia and an experienced clinician; otherwise she will be booked for delivery in a higher-acuity unit with on-call availability.” Or specify that delivery-location booking and anesthesia consult must be finalized by a particular gestational age.

key_information.suggested_changes: Tighten and focus details while adding missing decision-relevant clinical context. Keep: gestational age, type III FGC with very small introitus, urinary/menstrual symptoms, prior traumatic birth with urgent cutting, language barrier and family interpreting (relevant to consent/coercion). Add: whether she can be examined adequately now, whether urinary obstruction/UTIs are recurrent, and what anesthesia options are available for elective vs intrapartum deinfibulation. Remove or streamline non-essential phrasing (e.g., “specialist clinic,” “older female relative”) unless tied explicitly to consent/privacy concerns.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Increase balance so neither option reads as the obvious ‘better’ medical choice. Add explicit, credible downsides to second-trimester deinfibulation (e.g., she fears stigma/family repercussions, may feel coerced given reliance on family interpreter, potential procedural complications, psychological retraumatization) and credible benefits to deferring until delivery (e.g., aligns with her preferences for privacy/avoiding family detection, avoids an additional procedure during pregnancy) while also acknowledging intrapartum risks (time pressure, emergent incision). Ensure the vignette states that both timing options are routinely used and supported by guidelines in appropriate settings.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the value tension unavoidable and central to timing (medical/obstetric safety vs psychosocial/cultural harm and patient’s preference). Explicitly state that both timing options are clinically acceptable but carry different kinds of harms: e.g., add that second‑trimester deinfibulation may reduce labor complications/urgent cutting but may increase social risk, distress, or intimate-partner conflict; whereas deferring preserves bodily status during pregnancy and may reduce immediate social fallout but increases likelihood of emergent incision, loss of control, or maternal/fetal risk at delivery.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce competing/side dilemmas (coercion/consent/translator issues) that could become the primary ethical conflict. Clarify that the patient has been offered a professional interpreter, confirms understanding, and is able to speak privately without relatives present, so the main dilemma remains timing of deinfibulation rather than whether consent is voluntary. Alternatively, if you want coercion to remain, explicitly state that she privately reiterates her preference and the decision is still specifically about timing, not whether to proceed against her wishes.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Neutralize language that makes one option sound medically preferred. Replace 'wants a safer, more controlled pregnancy this time' and 'traumatic prior delivery that required urgent cutting at the time of birth' with balanced phrasing: e.g., 'She hopes to avoid an unplanned incision during labor but is anxious about undergoing a genital procedure while pregnant.' Add a sentence that obstetric consultants disagree and that outcomes are acceptable with either planned second‑trimester deinfibulation or planned intrapartum deinfibulation in an experienced unit, with different tradeoffs (planned recovery vs risk of urgent intervention, privacy, and family repercussions).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove potentially loaded or leading phrasing that frames one option as inherently safer or portrays family as coercive. For example, change “wants a safer, more controlled pregnancy this time” to “wants to discuss options to reduce intrapartum complications” and change “worries about her family’s reaction” to “anticipates interpersonal consequences within her household/community.” Also avoid implying the husband/relative are obstructive; describe them neutrally as accompanying persons.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten the vignette by removing redundant details and clarifying decision urgency. Combine symptom list and prior delivery into one sentence; clarify whether she is multiparous and whether urinary obstruction/UTIs are present. Specify why staffing/location planning requires a decision now (e.g., midwifery-led unit vs obstetric theatre, anesthesia availability). Remove “urgent cutting” and replace with a clinical term (e.g., “intrapartum deinfibulation under emergent conditions”).

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Replace potentially triggering or graphic phrasing with clinical terminology. Change “urgent cutting at the time of birth” to “emergency intrapartum deinfibulation.” Consider using “female genital cutting (FGC)” consistently and avoid vivid descriptors; keep anatomy description clinical (e.g., “markedly narrowed introitus consistent with type III FGC”).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make both options parallel, neutral, and within ~10–15 words, avoiding timing ambiguity and adding the shared elements (informed consent, plan). Example: 1) “Plan elective second-trimester deinfibulation after consent, with obstetric follow-up.” 2) “Plan intrapartum deinfibulation at delivery after consent, with contingency planning.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Neutralize framing that makes second-trimester deinfibulation seem medically/psychologically superior. For example: (1) Remove/soften "traumatic prior delivery that required urgent cutting" or explicitly state that either planned intrapartum deinfibulation or antenatal deinfibulation can avoid an emergency situation when appropriately planned. (2) Add a countervailing downside to second-trimester deinfibulation (e.g., patient fears losing privacy, risk of intimate partner violence/family retaliation if physical changes are noticed during pregnancy, or heightened psychological distress) and a clear downside to intrapartum-only deinfibulation (e.g., less time for healing before postpartum period, potential need for more extensive perineal repair, or limited ability to pause/stop once labor is underway). (3) Clarify that her urinary/menstrual symptoms are chronic but stable and do not require urgent intervention now.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Make the binary exhaustive by explicitly ruling out realistic middle options. Either: (A) State that only two institutionally feasible windows exist (e.g., operating room access available only during a scheduled 2nd-trimester clinic block; otherwise the only option is in-labor deinfibulation), and that she declines preconception/postpartum deinfibulation. OR (B) Expand choices so they truly span the space, e.g., Choice 1: perform deinfibulation during pregnancy (specify timing) vs Choice 2: do not perform deinfibulation during pregnancy and proceed with planned cesarean/delivery management without it. If you keep the current two options, explicitly exclude third-trimester or postpartum deinfibulation and explain why "wait and decide later" is not workable beyond generic staffing.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, common professional guidance often recommends antenatal (often 2nd-trimester) deinfibulation when feasible, which risks making Choice 1 the guideline-aligned answer. Fix by adding one of: (1) Explicitly state that local specialist guidance is split and both timings are accepted standards at this institution (e.g., maternal-fetal medicine recommends antenatal; the FGM specialist service recommends intrapartum to reduce social risk), or that the guideline is permissive and emphasizes patient preference without a recommended timing. (2) Add patient-specific factors that make guidelines non-determinative (e.g., severe fear of social harm if deinfibulated before birth; inability to ensure confidential follow-up; anticipated need for general anesthesia now vs local at delivery), making both options consistent with standards rather than one clearly preferred.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Rephrase language that implies one timing is medically superior. For example, change “wants a safer, more controlled pregnancy this time” to “hopes to avoid an unplanned emergency incision during labor” and explicitly note that either timing is clinically acceptable but carries different types of risks (e.g., second-trimester procedure risks: bleeding/infection/pain/psychological distress; intrapartum procedure risks: need for urgent incision, limited time for anesthesia/consent, higher risk of perineal trauma). Avoid wording that frames antepartum deinfibulation as the objectively ‘safer’ option.
decision_forcing_context: Make the time pressure concrete and clinically realistic. E.g., add: “Her next visit is in 2 weeks, and if deinfibulation is planned during pregnancy it needs to be scheduled before 20–24 weeks to coordinate anesthesia and an experienced clinician; otherwise she will be booked for delivery in a higher-acuity unit with on-call availability.” Or specify that delivery-location booking and anesthesia consult must be finalized by a particular gestational age.

Keep: gestational age, type III FGC with very small introitus, urinary/menstrual symptoms, prior traumatic birth with urgent cutting, language barrier and family interpreting (relevant to consent/coercion). Add: whether she can be examined adequately now, whether urinary obstruction/UTIs are recurrent, and what anesthesia options are available for elective vs intrapartum deinfibulation. Remove or streamline non-essential phrasing (e.g., “specialist clinic,” “older female relative”) unless tied explicitly to consent/privacy concerns.
non_triviality: Increase balance so neither option reads as the obvious ‘better’ medical choice. Add explicit, credible downsides to second-trimester deinfibulation (e.g., she fears stigma/family repercussions, may feel coerced given reliance on family interpreter, potential procedural complications, psychological retraumatization) and credible benefits to deferring until delivery (e.g., aligns with her preferences for privacy/avoiding family detection, avoids an additional procedure during pregnancy) while also acknowledging intrapartum risks (time pressure, emergent incision). Ensure the vignette states that both timing options are routinely used and supported by guidelines in appropriate settings.
feedback.ethical:
clarity_value_conflict: Make the value tension unavoidable and central to timing (medical/obstetric safety vs psychosocial/cultural harm and patient’s preference). Explicitly state that both timing options are clinically acceptable but carry different kinds of harms: e.g., add that second‑trimester deinfibulation may reduce labor complications/urgent cutting but may increase social risk, distress, or intimate-partner conflict; whereas deferring preserves bodily status during pregnancy and may reduce immediate social fallout but increases likelihood of emergent incision, loss of control, or maternal/fetal risk at delivery.
interpretive_consensus: Reduce competing/side dilemmas (coercion/consent/translator issues) that could become the primary ethical conflict. Clarify that the patient has been offered a professional interpreter, confirms understanding, and is able to speak privately without relatives present, so the main dilemma remains timing of deinfibulation rather than whether consent is voluntary. Alternatively, if you want coercion to remain, explicitly state that she privately reiterates her preference and the decision is still specifically about timing, not whether to proceed against her wishes.
decision_equipoise: Neutralize language that makes one option sound medically preferred. Replace 'wants a safer, more controlled pregnancy this time' and 'traumatic prior delivery that required urgent cutting at the time of birth' with balanced phrasing: e.g., 'She hopes to avoid an unplanned incision during labor but is anxious about undergoing a genital procedure while pregnant.' Add a sentence that obstetric consultants disagree and that outcomes are acceptable with either planned second‑trimester deinfibulation or planned intrapartum deinfibulation in an experienced unit, with different tradeoffs (planned recovery vs risk of urgent intervention, privacy, and family repercussions).
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove potentially loaded or leading phrasing that frames one option as inherently safer or portrays family as coercive. For example, change “wants a safer, more controlled pregnancy this time” to “wants to discuss options to reduce intrapartum complications” and change “worries about her family’s reaction” to “anticipates interpersonal consequences within her household/community.” Also avoid implying the husband/relative are obstructive; describe them neutrally as accompanying persons.
conciseness_coherence: Tighten the vignette by removing redundant details and clarifying decision urgency. Combine symptom list and prior delivery into one sentence; clarify whether she is multiparous and whether urinary obstruction/UTIs are present. Specify why staffing/location planning requires a decision now (e.g., midwifery-led unit vs obstetric theatre, anesthesia availability). Remove “urgent cutting” and replace with a clinical term (e.g., “intrapartum deinfibulation under emergent conditions”).
safety_compliance: Replace potentially triggering or graphic phrasing with clinical terminology. Change “urgent cutting at the time of birth” to “emergency intrapartum deinfibulation.” Consider using “female genital cutting (FGC)” consistently and avoid vivid descriptors; keep anatomy description clinical (e.g., “markedly narrowed introitus consistent with type III FGC”).

feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Neutralize framing that makes second-trimester deinfibulation seem medically/psychologically superior. For example: (1) Remove/soften "traumatic prior delivery that required urgent cutting" or explicitly state that either planned intrapartum deinfibulation or antenatal deinfibulation can avoid an emergency situation when appropriately planned. (2) Add a countervailing downside to second-trimester deinfibulation (e.g., patient fears losing privacy, risk of intimate partner violence/family retaliation if physical changes are noticed during pregnancy, or heightened psychological distress) and a clear downside to intrapartum-only deinfibulation (e.g., less time for healing before postpartum period, potential need for more extensive perineal repair, or limited ability to pause/stop once labor is underway). (3) Clarify that her urinary/menstrual symptoms are chronic but stable and do not require urgent intervention now.
exhaustive_binary_options: Make the binary exhaustive by explicitly ruling out realistic middle options. Either: (A) State that only two institutionally feasible windows exist (e.g., operating room access available only during a scheduled 2nd-trimester clinic block; otherwise the only option is in-labor deinfibulation), and that she declines preconception/postpartum deinfibulation. OR (B) Expand choices so they truly span the space, e.g., Choice 1: perform deinfibulation during pregnancy (specify timing) vs Choice 2: do not perform deinfibulation during pregnancy and proceed with planned cesarean/delivery management without it. If you keep the current two options, explicitly exclude third-trimester or postpartum deinfibulation and explain why "wait and decide later" is not workable beyond generic staffing.
no_guideline_override: As written, common professional guidance often recommends antenatal (often 2nd-trimester) deinfibulation when feasible, which risks making Choice 1 the guideline-aligned answer. Fix by adding one of: (1) Explicitly state that local specialist guidance is split and both timings are accepted standards at this institution (e.g., maternal-fetal medicine recommends antenatal; the FGM specialist service recommends intrapartum to reduce social risk), or that the guideline is permissive and emphasizes patient preference without a recommended timing. (2) Add patient-specific factors that make guidelines non-determinative (e.g., severe fear of social harm if deinfibulated before birth; inability to ensure confidential follow-up; anticipated need for general anesthesia now vs local at delivery), making both options consistent with standards rather than one clearly preferred.

data.vignette: A 21-year-old asylum seeker is 10 weeks pregnant at her first antenatal visit. She has limited English and arrives with her husband and a female relative, but you arrange a professional interpreter and speak with her alone. Pelvic exam shows a markedly narrowed introitus consistent with type III female genital cutting. She has long-standing dysuria and difficulty with menses but no acute retention or infection. In a prior birth, she needed intrapartum deinfibulation and describes the experience as frightening. She wants to reduce the chance of an unplanned incision during labor but is anxious about a genital procedure while pregnant and anticipates interpersonal consequences if physical changes are noticed before delivery. Maternal–fetal medicine and the FGC specialist service both consider either second-trimester or planned intrapartum deinfibulation acceptable in experienced hands. Hospital policy and current law permit either with informed consent. The service can offer elective deinfibulation only during a scheduled second-trimester block before 22 weeks; otherwise the only feasible option is intrapartum deinfibulation, and she declines postpartum intervention. A plan is needed by her next visit to book delivery location and anesthesia.
data.choice_2: Plan deinfibulation only during labor and delivery

data.vignette: A 21-year-old asylum seeker is 10 weeks pregnant at her first antenatal visit. She has limited English and arrives with her husband and a female relative, but you arrange a professional interpreter and speak with her alone. Pelvic exam shows a markedly narrowed introitus consistent with type III female genital cutting. She has long-standing dysuria and difficulty with menses but no acute retention or infection. In a prior birth, she needed intrapartum deinfibulation and describes the experience as frightening. She wants to reduce the chance of an unplanned incision during labor but is anxious about a genital procedure while pregnant and anticipates interpersonal consequences if physical changes are noticed before delivery. Maternal–fetal medicine and the FGC specialist service both consider either second-trimester or planned intrapartum deinfibulation acceptable in experienced hands. Hospital policy and current law permit either with informed consent. The service can offer elective deinfibulation only during a scheduled second-trimester block before 22 weeks; otherwise the only feasible option is intrapartum deinfibulation, and she declines postpartum intervention. A plan is needed by her next visit to book delivery location and anesthesia.

choice_2.choice: Plan deinfibulation only during labor and delivery

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause making her preference explicit (e.g., “She states she does not want deinfibulation during pregnancy and requests it only in labor,” or the reverse), so one option clearly aligns with her informed choice and the other would override it.

Add a clause stating that intrapartum-only deinfibulation carries a higher likelihood of emergency incision/tearing and worse maternal pain/bleeding compared with a planned second-trimester procedure, and/or that second-trimester deinfibulation would likely relieve her chronic urinary/menstrual symptoms and reduce delivery complications.

Add a clause specifying the key harm tradeoff (e.g., second‑trimester deinfibulation carries a small but real risk of bleeding/infection/pregnancy loss, whereas intrapartum-only deinfibulation has higher risk of emergent incision/hemorrhage/psychological trauma if labor is rapid or complicated).

data.vignette: A 21-year-old asylum seeker is 10 weeks pregnant at her first antenatal visit. She has limited English and arrives with her husband and a female relative. You arrange a professional interpreter and speak with her alone. Exam shows a markedly narrowed introitus consistent with type III female genital cutting. She has long-standing dysuria and difficult menses but no acute retention or infection. In a prior birth, she required intrapartum deinfibulation and found it frightening. Second-trimester deinfibulation would likely relieve her urinary and menstrual symptoms and reduce the chance of emergency cutting, tearing, and severe pain or bleeding in labor. It also carries a small risk of bleeding, infection, and pregnancy loss. She states she does not want a genital procedure during pregnancy and requests deinfibulation only in labor, partly due to concerns if physical changes are noticed before delivery. Specialists consider either timing acceptable with informed consent under hospital policy and law. Elective deinfibulation is only available in a scheduled second-trimester block before 22 weeks; otherwise it must be done intrapartum. A plan is needed by her next visit to book delivery location and anesthesia.

choice_2.choice: Plan deinfibulation only during labor and delivery

data.vignette: A 21-year-old asylum seeker is 10 weeks pregnant at her first antenatal visit. She has limited English and arrives with her husband and a female relative. You arrange a professional interpreter and speak with her alone. Exam shows a markedly narrowed introitus consistent with type III female genital cutting. She has long-standing dysuria and difficult menses but no acute retention or infection. In a prior birth, she required intrapartum deinfibulation and found it frightening. Second-trimester deinfibulation would likely relieve her urinary and menstrual symptoms and reduce the chance of emergency cutting, tearing, and severe pain or bleeding in labor. It also carries a small risk of bleeding, infection, and pregnancy loss. She states she does not want a genital procedure during pregnancy and requests deinfibulation only in labor, partly due to concerns if physical changes are noticed before delivery. Specialists consider either timing acceptable with informed consent under hospital policy and law. Elective deinfibulation is only available in a scheduled second-trimester block before 22 weeks; otherwise it must be done intrapartum. A plan is needed by her next visit to book delivery location and anesthesia.

choice_2.choice: Plan deinfibulation only during labor and delivery
